intro: Pycreus pseudodiaphanus var. occidentalis, commonly known as the western ghostflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescence and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its flowers are small and white, often appearing in clusters, and it is known for its delicate, ephemeral blooms. The species is of interest to botanists due to its unique ecological niche and limited distribution.
